author: gleetk

title: Hand Spinner Fidget With Ball Bearings

description.text:
I designed this fidget toy to reduce the number of bearings needed compared to similar designs. I used a cheaper 22mm double shielded bearing at the center. I removed the shields with a pick (be careful) and cleaned it out with brake cleaner and compressed air. This increased the spin time from 10-20 seconds to over a minute.
I chose to install a 5/16" thumb nut and button head cap screw through the center bearing. The added standoff distance helps keep your hands clear when spinning and allows for placing the spinner on a flat surface and really get it moving.
I used 3/8" diameter ball bearings for the outside weights. The model is sized at .018-.019" oversized for the bearing and balls as my prints typically shrink that amount. Scale as needed for desired fit. When I printed the bearings and balls pressed in by hand with an audible click.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Printed using ABS filament. I used a 5mm brim and ABS slurry on the bed (90 degree) for adhesion. My printer has an e3D v6 hot end upgrade but is otherwise stock.

After printing I removed the brim. I then sanded with 220 grit sandpaper to smooth all faces and edges. Following that I used small amounts of acetone on a rag to create a glossy finish.
To ensure the bearings and balls don't come loose, I wet each with acetone before installing in the spinner to "weld" them in place. This will only work if ABS is used.

comments.text: What kind of bearing exact dimensions ??
comments.author: Dkelly21

comments.text: The bearings I used were 608ZZ double shielded miniature ball bearings 8mm (ID) x 22mm (OD) x 7mm (H). The actual outside diameter is 21.98mm.
comments.author: Dkelly21

comments.author: Dakota_134

comments.text: The steel ball bearings are 3/8" diameter.

title: External Case for a Mini-ITX GTX 970 and EXP GDC Adapter (v8.0)

description.text:
This is an External Case for a Gigabyte Mini-ITX GTX 970 (GV-N970IXOC-4GD) and the EXP GDC External Video Card Adapter (v8.0) to allow the card to run external on my laptop. I'm using this mostly for a portable Oculus Rift laptop, so I've also included the face-plate with the Oculus logo.
I didn't include the .stl for the handle, as it isn't my design. If you would like a handle you can download this handle, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:179261 and scale it to size. The top of the case where the handle is mounted is a 156mm in length, but the handle I'm using is 148mm in length.
I'm using 3M foam Double stick tape to mount the face-plate to the case, as I didn't want to use screws. I've travel quite a bit with the case now and have had no issues.

title: Arduino+Shield Cooling Fan Adapter (120 mm Case Fan)

description.text:
I printed these parts to prevent my DRV8825 chips, 6V servo power supply, and L298 chip on a custom designed Arduino Mega shield from overheating. It uses a 120mm computer case fan to cool the parts, and so far it has worked very well. The arduino mega slides into the side slots which are spaced so that the shield is slightly higher than it should be, because the shield has pins over the USB port. 
Best part: the lights on the board look super cool through my clear fan...

title: VW Corrado heater control light repair / led conversion( 535919383 )

description.text:
Once in a while the heater control backlight lamp dies. VW produced the part in 1 piece. You have to replace the whole unit if only the lamp dies. Unit is expensive and not produced anymore. I replaced the bulp with a white led. The led has a resistor for 12v use, find it on Ebay or at DX. I like to keep my car and loom original so i also post a adapter that can be used to connect de loom connector to the cut lamp connector en keep it in place.
  • cut the lamp holder from the heater control unit
  • make the lamp hole a bit wider so the led can go in
  • (if you don't want to cut the loom) cut the lamp holder so you can solder the led wires to the pins
  • put the parts toghetter.
    • ps. no need for glue, the part fits tight to the original EDIT: i added the right side, using 1 bulb did not light up the whole heater control. Adding a led on the other side does light it up in total. For maximum result grind away a bit of the white plastic so the led can easely shine tru. Again no glue needed part can pushed between plastic heater conntrol parts.

If you want to print it with two colors too, change the color after the 15th layer.

No

Yes

0.2

20%

if you wonder why the protector is bulbous, the reason is to give the incoming air the least resistance.

geetech ie B pro

mid

title: CiiiCooler for Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Maker Select
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The DiiiCooler is a better cooler, but the CiiiCooler is a good alternative. [RECOMMENDED RADIAL FANS]
Duplicator i3 V1, V2, V2.1 (12V): www.banggood.com/3Pcs-3D-Printer-12V-DC-50mm50mm-Blow-Radial-Cooling-Fan-p-1121554.html
Duplicator i3 PLUS (24V): www.banggood.com/3Pcs-DC24V-Cooling-Fan-Ultra-Quiet-Turbine-Small-DC-Blower-5015-For-3D-Printer-Circuit-Board-p-1110725.html
(For the 24V fan you may have to switch cable orientation in the connector to fit the PLUS) The CiiiCooler is a cooler that is to be mounted around the hotend of the Wanhao Duplicator i3.
It provides a 300 degree field of cooling around the hotend for the part being printed.
It sacrifices 60 degree of field compared to the DiiiCooler, but provides a view of the nozzle and a more even flow of air around the nozzle compared to a directional or bi-directional cooler. Print this item without support; in ABS, PET-G or other filaments that can stand a bit of heat.
(PLA has worked when testing the prototypes, but use it at your own risk.)
Print the CiiiCooler with the flat bottom down against the bed. [CHOOSING THE RIGHT CIIICOOLER]
CiiiCooler_1-32.STL will work for most printers out there.
CiiiCooler_SHORT_1-32.STL This mounts 2 mm higher up and should only be used if the default one above is too low and hitting the heatbed. [ATTENTION V2.1 OWNERS]
You will need to print the adapter named CiiiCooler_Adapter_V2-1 to be able to mount this cooler to Wanhao's latest V2.1 bearing holders. [REQUIRED HARDWARE]
1 pcs M4x20 screw
1 pcs M4 nut (or locknut)
2 pcs M4x12 (For V1.0 and V2.0 Owners)
2 pcs M4x25 (For V2.1 Owners)
1 pcs CiiiCooler_Adapter_V2-1 (For V2.1 Owners, from download scection)
1 pcs 51x51x15 mm radial fan (Look at Delta BFB0512HH for dimensions datasheet) [MOUNTING INSTRUCTIONS FOR V1.0 and V2.0]
1) Thread the lowest 2 holes of the lowest bearing block with M4 tap.
2) Align the CiiiCooler around the heaterblock and fasten it with the M4 screws.
3) Attach the radial fan to the CiiiCooler with the M4 screws and nut and connect the fan. [MOUNTING INSTRUCTIONS FOR V2.1]
1) Put the adapter on the lowest bearing block with the holes down.
2) Place the CiiiCooler against the adapter and fasten it with the M4 screws.
3) Attach the radial fan to the CiiiCooler with the M4 screws and nut and connect the fan. [NOZZLE DISTANCE]
The recommended distance from under the flat surface of cooler to the tip of the nozzle is 1-3mm for optimal performance. [PID HEAT MANAGER] (use for best hotend performance)
This describes how to make your Duplicator i3 use PID heat management for best temperature control of the hotend, no matter which cooler you use.
(For best results, perform your own PID-tuning.)
Using Repetier-Host, go into [Config] -> [Firmware EEPROM Configuration]
Change the following parameters:
Extr.1 heat manager [0-3] = 1
Extr.1 PID P-gain/dead-time = 7
Extr.1 PID I-gain 0.5
Extr.1 PID D-gain 25 [ADAPTERS FOR OTHER PRINTERS]
Wanhao Di3 PLUS - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2011571 (By Castle550)
Wanhao Di3 PLUS - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2050157 (By jcheger) [DONATIONS]
If you're enjoying this design and find it improves your print quality, please consider sending a tip.
Click "TIP DESIGNER" here.

comments.text:
Is it possible to get a "mirrored" version of this cooler so the fan can mount upside down?
The Wanhao i3 Plus requires a modified PCB mount (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2050157) which means the fan's intake is mushed into a tiny space.
Directly "mirroring" the whole print doesn't work because the mounting holes are slightly off-center. The resulting print will have the cooler touching the hot end.

Great so see a better version of the Diiicooler. The bad view on the nozzle (and the hassle when changing the nozzle) was the main reason why I didn't use it - but now it's about time to try that out. BTW: I see you're still using a noctua fan for cooling the filament (like I did) - don't you have problems with it? I recently changed it for a stronger fan because I found out it's too weak and was causing unsteady filament flow (which also produced bad perimeters like I can see on your picture of the green Ciiicooler). And it looks like at least another person had that problem too:
http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/i3/topic:10725#comment-1146576
comments.author: unwohlpol

comments.text:
As written in the description, the DiiiCooler is still a better cooler, but CiiiCooler a good alternative if wanting to see the nozzle ;).
No problem at all using the Noctua to cool the coldend of the extruder, by my machine is one of the first V1.0 available. I think they later on changed motors and didnt change driver settings so extruder motor (and the others) were driven with too much current causing them to overheat.
The unstable filament flow I got going is likely due to bad quality filament (Market as PLA but wouldnt be supriced if it's a PLA/ABS mix, it's just a super cheap filament I'm trying to use up, if I change to the brand I usually use, the problem goes away.
I guess the combo of cheap bad quality filament and weaker coldend cooling can cause issues, but no issues with higher quality filaments for me at least :)

comments.text:
The Diii and Ciii coolers work on two completely different flow principles. A 360 degree CiiiCooler will still not be as good as a DiiiCooler.
I have optimized the CiiiCooler to have as large of a view angle as possible without sacrificing the performance that the principle works on, reducing the view angle wont make much of a difference (and without re-optimizing the flowpath entirely it will actually make it worse since it will make the airflow uneven)

comments.text:
The performance will be less than DiiiCooler, but more even flow around the nozzle than a Cobra or Thorped. I have only done simulations to verify this since I havnt had time to make a cooling performance test. But have verified the flowpath of the cooler is according to simulation on an actual printed CiiiCooler.
If you do try the different coolers I do encourage you to try it out yourself if you wish to see if it affects your prints, it's very time consuming task to make such tests, something I dont have time to do at the moment.
(You need to print several test parts, all at different orientation around the hotend to see how a rotational angle affects the print quality, and you will need to try different temperatures etc. I at least ~50 hours on it on the DiiiCooler to get results I could compare fairly, I do not have the time for that now.

author: MICROLOGT

description.text:
This is a enclosure that I use on my DIY electric longboard. It is designed to host two Turnigy 3s 5000mah lipos as well as connectors for charger and a 2x3s to 6s balance connector board and a power switch board and switch. There are no pre drilled holes in the model making it easier to make cut outs and holes where its needed later.
The part is modeld to fit the radius of a Madrid Weezer 36” longboard. The five splitted parts are printed one by one on my Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2 at 0.3mm layer hight, 3 perimeters for both the walls and top/bottom. I used PLA for this print.
I then used loctite superglue and friction welding to bond the parts together. The hatch part is used as a lid to the cutout in the main piece where the connectors for the charger will sit as well as ability to connect a limo guard. And the pipe part is used to host the cables running to the VESC housing.

author: LenHu

description.text:
Here’s a special effector I designed to mount a laser engraving module on my delta 3D printer. The advantage is that it can be mounted and disassembled without disturbing the settings and the mechanical parts of the printer. It’s placed in a simple slide and locked by a small part. You can switch quickly and easily from printing to engraving. When the laser isn’t mounted, it can be placed on its support on the side of the printer. In addition, the two radial fans provide optimum cooling for 3D printing. The laser is positioned at -42.5mm on the Y axis with respect to the nozzle. I glued a wooden disc on a borosilicate disc with the same difference. The engraving bed is simply moved but the available area remains the same. List of parts to be printed (without supports) :
  • Effector
  • Mounting bracket (print with 10% filling, supports already included)
  • Locking effector part
  • Diffusers (to be glued into the fans)
  • Laser slide
  • Locking slide part
  • Laser support (if needed)
    • List of screws required :
  • 4x M3*8mm
  • 1x M3*10mm
  • 6x M3*12mm
  • 3x M3*16mm
  • 2x M3*20mm
  • (2x M4*8mm and nuts, if laser support is needed)
    • List of material :
  • Laser Module (for exemple : https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/Focusable-Diode-Laser-1000mW-450nm-Blue-Laser-Module-with-TTL-Driver-for-laser-engraving-machine-cnc/32642400998.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.tTVbcP)
  • 2x radial fans 50*50mm
  • Axial fan 30*30mm
    • Softwares : To engrave an image :
  • Laser Etch B/W Image Engraving by J Tech Photonics (https://jtechphotonics.com/?product=laser-etch-bw-image-engraving-sw-license). This program decomposes a BMP image into lines and generates the gcode. The engraving is done line after line as an impression.
    • To engrave outline and to cut :
  • Inkscape (https://inkscape.org/en/) + Inkscape Laser Plug-In by J Tech Photonics (https://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=2012). Delta printers doesn’t support G2 and G3 arcs commands, so for the moment, I have not found any other solution than to break arcs in linear segmentations. In Inkscape I use the function : Extensions > ModifyPaths > Flatten Beziers.
    • Ask me if you are interested in the electrical connections and softwares configuration. I will add more info if needed. Have fun and think safety first by protecting your eyes ! ;)

title: Heavy Duty Ice Scraper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My old and beloved brass ice scraper broke. I could have used two-component adhesive to fix this but since the shape of the ice scraper was pretty bad in terms of usability anyway, I decided to build my own scraper. A word on usability: I believe that most commercially available ice scrapers have a faulty design especially with respect to the handle. The longer the handle gets, the more difficult it is to apply proper force on the scraper part. So much the worse the harder the ice. mishmish4 designed a nice, short and sturdy Dual Function Ice Scraper. The twist-in-place handle is a nice design detail, but, to my mind, it does not add to usability. I used this design as the basis for my Heavy Duty Ice Scraper. Unfortunately, mishmish4's STL was not editable for me in SketchUp so I redesigned that thing anew omitting the handle and chosing a somewhat sleeker design. Please note that there are two versions available:

  • Heavy Duty Ice Scraper FINAL.stl -- This one has a 4cm diameter grip bar. You should have fairly big hands to achieve a decent scraping job with this.

  • Heavy Duty Ice Scraper FINAL (oval).stl -- This one has a ~3.5cm diameter at the widest side of the grip bar. I squeezed the scraper along the vertical axis so the grip bar is now oval instead of round. I think that this one is better to handle but, again, it depends on the size of your hands.

    • The SketchUp files are provided in case you want to make adjustments or remix the scraper.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.16mm

Infill:

66%

Notes: Definitely print the scraper on its side. This way you will not need support and the printing time is reduced. The combination of 66% infill with a shell thickness of 1.2mm yielded a pretty sturdy scraper.

To upgrade a table built from 40mm profile to be moveable, wheels were needed.
Those able to carry the weight had 50x50mm fixture.
This is an adapter to mount these wheels to a 40mm profile. Corners hold metric nuts M6 to mount the wheel, center hole is 6.5mm to mount into the profile using M6 screw. Wheels are limited to about 40kg each, PLA can easily cope with that.

Printer:

DIY-Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: High infill to carry up to 50kg per wheel.
Maybe 20% would have been sufficient. Support in the corners and in the center is needed for clean printing.

title: Make #11 - Treat Time Sleigh
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: What better way to serve up Yuletide treats than in Santa's sleigh. Fill with something sweet and hang on your tree! Faberdashery are releasing daily, seasonal designs for you to print and enjoy. Join in the fun with our 25 Days of Making! This is Make #11 of 25.

Slice with 2 shells (/perimeters) and 1% infill. At coarse resolution (0.3mm), you will find prints have extra shimmer (and print quicker!).
Created in stunning Faberdashery Mercury Red PLA^. This print requires ~14g of material (~2m of 3mm / ~6m of 1.75mm filament). The two halves of the Sleigh push-fit together, with handles either side to add decorative twine for hanging.

Something to keep the filament from falling off a full reel.  For some reason the filament on the reels I have was twisted when it was put on the reel, so every so often it would fall off the side of the reel and it prevented the filament feeding properly.  With these clips it doesn't do that anymore.
The scad file is parameterized so you can change it to fit your reels.  It's currently set to make 6 of them 45mm long and to fit a 1.9 thick edge on the reel.

remixed_from.author: Allted
remixed_from.title: Mostly Printed CNC -Add On- MK Extruder

title: MPCNC MK8Extruder Ringfan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A circular part cooling duct for 30mm fans. Tested while printing and with smoke. Not the biggest cooling effect but very evenly and not effecting the nozzle too much.
  • Updated with a 40mm fan version and optimized airflow.
  • Updated with a 40mm fan B variant that has an additional duct blowing directly under the nozzle.
  • Updated with the final 40mm variant with larger opening on the bottom and an additional shroud that uses the hotend fan to direct more air to the print. This combination produced best results.
  • Added STEP and IGES files for modification :)
    • I did a simulation to test the airflow and it matches the results I observed when testing with smoke. You can watch it here https://youtu.be/EhtRSBZZycE

Printer:

MPCNC

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20

Notes: It is better to print without brim if you can get enough adhesion otherwise it´s difficult to clean it out afterwards on the opening. There is a small gap below the fan but it prints good enough without support. Use a 0,3mm first layer to make it sit flat on the print table.
Print the shroud with support on the inside. 80° Overhang angle worked for me.
It is meant to be fixed with a M4 screw to allteds MK8 mount. I directly screwed it into the hole woithout a nut. It can be adjusted in x,y and z with a slot and a additional nut.

comments.text: So, I have a mini-kossel type printer, with a metal effector, a ring collar, and all of that is metal.  No place to mount anything.  I built hooks, one type that fits into the gap, the other type hooks over the flat part, they take threaded inserts from the other side so that there is a mm of plastic under the inserts and they won't pull through.  I am using a cooling shroud that attaches to these hooks as if they were a wade mount.

A magnetic toy made from simple curiosity and spare neodymium magnets. Print the STL as is in the material of your choice. Prints well in ABS at 230C and bed temp of 110C. No warping. Also BEAUTIFUL print in PETG at proper temp settings.
Small neodymium magnets superglued beneath base and bottom of seahorse. Seahorse hung by regular old sewing thread. The placement of magnets and length of thread determine the magnetic action. title: static electricity protection knob cover Taz 5... terrible name suggestions welcome

description.text: Protect your Taz5 and possibly other conducting-knobbed printers with comparably sized control/tune knob before you shock the bajezus out of your printer again! So when the winter air hit, I found that the generation of static electricity was becoming a hazard to my printer... and prints. After I inadvertently delivered a few shocks to my Taz 5 with subsequent frozen-in-place prints, I decided to make something to protect it from myself. The new Taz 6 comes with a plastic knob, probably for this exact reason, but my knob is metallic and conducts electricity. Its a good sturdy knob and I didn't wanna go out purchasing new hardware (set screws and such) so I just made a sleeve/cover to insulate it from me and my static covered self. It friction grips in place and has a hole to access your set screw which is a T-6 btw. Mine came out great with T-glase and even allows for visibility of the (yes worthless) little arrow on the knob. May require ever so slight rescaling on your printer as we've all seen with fine prints so +/- 1% or so probably max. If you love this knob cover so much you wanna cover all the other knobs in your life with one and dont want the set screw hole, ive included an arbitrary knob cover file as well. happy printer protecting!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.18

Infill:

doesnt matter

Notes: I have a 0.5mm nozzle on my taz and it still made the teeth inside nicely and took about 20-25 min total print. if you dont mind pausing prints, I'd say let it get to about z=5 and GENTLY test fit the knob into the print.

comments.text: Hahaha! I found this looking for upgrades to our new Taz5 and it's everything I need! I shock the printer a lot because my chair rolls on a thin rug while I work on the desktop. Every shock resets the board and every time I have a mini panic attack I fried the thing. Your are our savior!
comments.author: billioncash

comments.text: Probably should have updated, I've learned that if the discharge doesn't go through the knob. It'll still go through the screws on the housing. I actually ended up putting a grounding wire near the printer to discharge on before touching the printer. I have the same carpet problem. The knob helps a little but it's not the end all.

title: Kit upgrade Anet A8 to Steel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The kit includes all needed parts to upgrade from the Anet A8 printer to the prusa Steel chassis. The idea is to make it as compatible as possible with the regular prusa, thus I will recomend to change de carriage and extruder, otherwise you will have to modify the distance between bars by mechanising your anet A8 carriage becouse the distance is different. Since it took me some time to find, adapt and design all the needed parts, I decided to put them all together in a single kit. I have ordered the photos so that the location of each part is easily identifiable. Thanks to Txispas, oloand an tooson for their excellent work. 13/07/2017 UPDATE: added part #090, X belt support adapted from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1666094 to the narrower distance when adapting the anet carriage as you can see in the picture #2..
Removed all parts related to chain.

author: c4sfer

description.text:
I wanted a fully inclosed quad to do proximity and to fly without worrying I was going to break it every other flight. I also wanted to push the boundaries of weight 
The Black Bee 115 is what I came up with. The T4b's Green Bee 110 inspired me, and I used the canopy from that design to fit my Black Bee. I enlarged the frame by 5mm just to offer a crashproof cushion. 
This thing is a blast to fly. With 1304 4000kv motors, with 3" props, and a small 3s battery it is fast, nimble and crashable! Print it in 910 Alloy to make it virtually unbreakable. ABS would be another decent choice.

remixed_from.author: wbarber69
remixed_from.title: printrbot play heated bed cable chain

description.text:
When I got my Printrbot Play, there was an issue with the main cable bundle getting caught behind the plate. There are several attempts to fix that with printed parts that keep the cable bundle high enough to not snap the plate. I was using one of these until I installed the heated bed. After I installed my Y-Axis/Heated bed upgrade onto my Printrbot Play, I was having an issue with the main cable bundle dragging across the back of the elongated bed and, often, knocking prints loose. This Thing is my solution to both problems. The 2 motor mounts are designed to be slid over the motors, then tightened in place with a M3 screw in each, 12mm or 16mm would work. The chain it designed with "up" links and "Down" links, meaning the link is opened on that side. This allows the wires to be inserted into the chain, 1 link at a time, without the need to unplug anything. I did need to extend my hot end thermistor and shroud fan wires as they were not quite long enough for the new routing through the chain. The chains are adapted from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1640019 PS: This is my first original creation and my tools are limited. please forgive the rough nature of some of the parts. Video of the chain in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BOUCFC49e_Q

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: The chain links do not need supports, but the motor brackets do. I printed everything on a raft. The "down" links tended to break loose without it.

description.text: Romero Britto Pop Art _brazilian Artist

Weather instrument with anemometer and wind vane.
Made with 4 printed parts.
  • there is a 5mm screw attached on the bottom part (40 mm long in my setup).
  • a 608zz bearing is fixed between rotor and cups with 3mm screws.
  • a 9mm magnet(from a bicycle odometer) is inserted on the rotor

  • the wind speed is calculated with a reed switch

  • for the wind vane, a continuous single turn potentiometer is used
    • Use with arduino as described here:
    http://cactus.io/hookups/weather/anemometer/davis/hookup-arduino-to-davis-anemometer-software Update: The electronic I use are the following:
  • one potentiometer for the wind vane, just an example bellow but can be other type. Secure it on the 'top' part.
    http://www.conrad.com/ce/en/product/1055299/Single-turn-rotary-pot-Mono-1-W-1-k-Bourns-1-pcs
  • one reed switch (any type) triggered by a magnet attached to the rotor. it is inserted from inside into a piece called, by me, 'bottom'. secure it with hot glue
  • an arduino mini to calculate the wind speed and direction
    https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/arduinoBoardProMini
    • I'm not good with electronics but I have managed to hook up the wires to arduino with the info I found online.
    The arduino code is the one from
    http://cactus.io/hookups/weather/anemometer/davis/hookup-arduino-to-davis-anemometer-wind-speed One M5 hexagonal screw attached and secured on the 'bottom' part will be the rotor axe.
    4 M3 40mm screws to join the main 2 parts (top & bottom) and 3 M3 20mm screws to fix the cups on the rotor. This project it's on hold until spring but I can share some results from testing it:
  • my potentiometer is hard to turn by hand and it's not so effective for wind direction.
  • the rotor it's easy to turn even on low winds and the readings are accurate
  • 4 wire connection for 5V and serial reading is attached to the arduino and you cannot reprogram it while the case is closed (because you need to press the reset button)
  • because is winter I didn't test it outside to calibrate it
    • UPDATE 2:

  • added new anemometer cups with support for 2 bearings
    http://www.thingiverse.com/download:3548001

  • First run:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S4hPwpiY1XQ

description.text: Hi! This is a generator for some kind of Skyscrapers. The main goal while designing this one is to have a 'Surface mode' printable figure. A fast printing mode for hollow figures. Useful for lamps, try to put some leds inside. The Customizer is easy to manage. Just set the number of sides of blocks, the 'levels' (affects af total height of figure) and an optional twist. There's no seed for randomness so every Customization generates 3 random STL's sightly differents of the preview. Include a ZIP file with a bunch of STL's generated during development. build me up, tear me down and have fun printing this one!!

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

No infill

Notes: I've learned a few things printing this in 'Surface mode'. Hope you find it useful 1.- Printing in surface mode needs a good bed adhesion. if you don't have heated bed (i don't) use hair spray or some kind of sticky glue 2.- Don't print too fast. I usually print at 60mm/s but get some 'holes' near corners in 'Surface mode'.Priting at 40mm/s works well for my printer 3.- Get more flow: I usually use between 75%-90% flow. For Surface mode i use 100-110% to avoid 'holes' and bad adhesion between layers. Some pieces generated have small parts 'floating' inside. Not a problem in most of figures but check carefully your layers in the slicer software to ensure a good printing

Look for 'Surface mode' in 'special modes' Check your layers This 'floating' parts are connected to figure in upper layers. Usually makes a bit of overhanging inside but the surface of figure prints well. Sometimes it's a mess

title: Ultimaker Bowden Fixer (BFX-01)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The bowden tube and black cable leading from the extruder to the back of the UM2 is not tied to anything, therefore both cables are flexing freely whenever the printer is printing. Although this wouldn't normally cause problems to the printer, fixing these cables in place will eliminate any possibility, as well as making everything more tidy on the printer.

The BFX01 is designed to be a single piece, therefore it's easy to print, install and looks elegant. It is designed to only be visible on the back of the printer, and does not affect the sides or front of the printer. Also there is no hinges, clamps or locking mechanism, means that the bowden tube and black cable can be easily mounted and removed.

The left screw hole screws into an existing screw that holds the printer's back panel and the top panel. The right screw sits on top of the back panel, it creates a tension between the BFX01 and the back panel to ensure the BFX01 stays in place. The last screw holds the bowden tube onto the BFX01, this makes it easy to take out the bowden tube at any moment without disassembling the BFX01.

There are several UM2 bowden fixers on youmagine that I have tried out but was too difficult to assemble, some come in several pieces which are pretty hard to attach. Therefore I designed from scratch with the idea to create the fixer as a single piece, and to find a nice area to mount it on the printer.
This helps me and the others to see if there are areas to improve on the design, as well as to show how it have helped your printer.

Notes: I rotated this model 180%, supports are required in all the slots.

A few years back I threw together a temperature and humidity project to test the humidity of my home before and after a whole home humidifier installation. The result was abysmal and the net change was barely detectable evan 60 days after installation so this quickly became a trinket on my desk to monitor the conditions of my office. Having acquired a 3D printer and having a desire to learn AutoDesk Fusion 360 I decided to give this project just a little more life, plus help to prevent damage from when it "accidently" falls off my desk because the cat wants knock it around my office. Pretty basic shell/bumper that has vents next to the temp/humid sensor (incase I do make a lid), a rear hole for a powered USB cable, and support posts that line up with the PCBs drill holes. The support posts provide 1 mm clearance from the base of the shell and the PCB fits in snuggly. If I did have to build this circuit again, I would change the location of some components, as it current layout make a lid a more time consuming task to design. I have included a few screen grabs from Fusion, an STL file, and the Arduino Code (ino) file. The Arduino Code has a nice pin out table as well as some decent comments (I surprise myself sometimes). Here is a link to the AutoDesk Fusion 360 Files Main Electronic Components:
DHT22
Perma-Proto Half-sized Breadboard PCB
ATmega328P
a .96" SPI Serial OLED from eBay

title: Remixed Pi 3 NES case bottom with Powerblock

description.text:
This is my remixed Mini NES Pi 3 Case by LKM in the upside down orientation (which is the best looking version of this, in my opinion). This version makes room for the Powerblock add-on board, as well as makes room for a power switch and an LED light. I gorilla glue'd the power switch and LED in place, which seems to have worked well. The fan has also been moved to the other side, which had plenty of open space. This is only the bottom STL file as the top of the case and the rest of the files should be the same and found on LKM's version. The closer two screw holes to the front of the case need to be longer m3 screws, but the back 2 screws can be the same size. The powerblock changes where the power adapter goes (Which I hate), so I had to dig out the power input on the front of the board right above the power switch. 
To not confuse, I found a micro USB cap and made it with ninjaflex filament, then stuck it over the original power adapter location of the Raspberry Pi 3.

author: Richie_i3

description.text:
This thing is just a SCAD script that provide an API to manipulate parts of a models by placing them relative to each other. When writing SCAD models i found out that the result scripts are not readable. Even when i read them myself many days later i don't understand what i wrote and why i wrote them this way. The main reason is that i use a lot of constant values computed or measured on parts in real life and even with comments in code this is hard to read. Furthermore when i want to make modifications i don't know where to apply them in code. This API simplify all my designs by allowing me to place parts relatives to each other.
This thing is designed using this library: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2005142

Each elementary part of the model (cube, cylinder etc...) can be bounded by a box that you create using the api boxCreate().
Boxes faces are always aligned with x,y,z axis. The boxCreate api just take the size of the box on [x,y,z] before any rotation: boundingBox = boxCreate ( [1, 1, 1] ); The object returned is an array on which we can get some computed values using indexes (which are all listed at the beginning or the file box.scad). For instance these indexes returns the size elements of the box. When the box is first created these are just the values we gave: boundingBox[idx] boundingBox[idy] boundingBox[idz] The following indexes returns the position values on x,y,z of the center of the box. The center of the box is the point that we move using transformations, it can be anywhere in the box. When the box is first created the center is the barycenter of all its points and it is placed at coordinate [0,0,0]: boundingBox[ix] boundingBox[iy] boundingBox[iz] The following indexes returns the x position of the left face: boundingBox[ixmin] boundingBox[ileft] The equivalences are made such you are the observer that look in the direction of Y axis with Z going top and X going right: ixmin = ileft ixmax = iright iymin = ifront iymax = iback izmin = ibottom izmax = itop

The box can be translated, rotated and resized. The object contains actualy 2 boxes: the outer box that we just saw (global coordinates) and the inner box (local coordinates).
To access to local coordinates, just add an l in indexes : ilxmin = illeft ilxmax = ilright ilymin = ilfront ilymax = ilback ilzmin = ilbottom ilzmax = iltop When the box is first created the local and global coordinates have the same values. But they will differ when you use transformations:
  • When you translate the box using boxTranslatexxx or boxMovexxx functions only the global box is translated, the local box stay unmodified,
  • When you rotate the box using boxRotatexxx functions only the global box is recomputed in order to hold the rotate part of the local box.
  • When you resize the box using boxResizexxx or boxExtrudexxx functions the local box is resized and the global box is recomputed in order to hold the rotate part of the local box.
    • Another way to explain this is: The global box is the bounding box of the local box after translation/rotation.

The following APIs allow you to get SCAD modules with elementary shapes bounded in a box:
  • boxRenderCube(bbox): this module builds a SCAD cube bounded in the local box, rotated and translated,
  • boxRenderCylinderX(bbox): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the X axis of the local box, rotated and translated,
  • boxRenderCylinderY(bbox): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the Y axis of the local box, rotated and translated,
  • boxRenderCylinderZ(bbox): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the Z axis of the local box, rotated and translated,
  • boxRenderConeRight(bbox, sd): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the X. The small diameter (sd) of the cone is placed on the right face of the local box,
  • boxRenderConeLeft(bbox, sd): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the X. The small diameter (sd) of the cone is placed on the left face of the local box,
  • boxRenderConeBack(bbox, sd): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the X. The small diameter (sd) of the cone is placed on the back face of the local box,
  • boxRenderConeFront(bbox, sd): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the X. The small diameter (sd) of the cone is placed on the front face of the local box,
  • boxRenderConeTop(bbox, sd): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the X. The small diameter (sd) of the cone is placed on the top face of the local box,
  • boxRenderConeBottom(bbox, sd): this module builds a SCAD cylinder oriented on the X. The small diameter (sd) of the cone is placed on the bottom face of the local box.
    • The cylinders diameters and cone large diameter are computed as the minimum value of the borders of the cylinder's/cone's base.
    Note that the resulting object is bounded by the global box.

The images of this thing is the result of the following scripts, as you can see the only scalar values are the initial bounding boxes of the items. These boxes are then moved and rotated with box API transformations and then rendered using box API modules (boxRenderxxx).

Guilty Crown - Inori's Void

author: jasmythe

description.text:
This is my recent entry for RemixChallenge. Inspired by three things on Thingiverse:
Articulated PCB Workstation by giufini http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:801279
Pointy Star by iamnotachoice http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:563306
And my own "ordinary" version of GU10 lamp http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1703148 Please keep best practices in mind during the construction [as also described in my original design]:

  • DO NOT use other than LED bulbs when printing with PLA. Otherwise the shades will get melted shortly and can cause the short circuit in the socket or cable.

  • You can glue GU10 socket inside the shade if needed, Eventually use 2 small screws in socket thru holes to tight it up inside.

  • Be careful with electrical wires and ensure the safety (insulate as appropriate if cable extension is needed, avoid short circuit to prevent the fire etc.)
    • The lamp was printed with gold PLA 1.75mm filament on Prusa I3.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

30%

• Remove the inner bridges in shade body - these are holding the GU10 insert during the print
  • Glue the shade body with the bottom star part (with hole in the middle) with super glue
  • Insert GU10 socket and tighten securely
  • Add joints as needed. 6 were use in this prototype
  • Connect the base to the last joint
  • Tighten the base with 3 countersunk screws to the piece of wood with hole for cable
  • Add extension cable if needed. Check the cable, connection and insulation carefully before connecting to wall plug
    • Enjoy the Christmas star light.
Design details Initially designed in FreeCAD then imported to OpenSCAD for starry enhancement.

author: Soeren3003

description.text:
A remixed version of Zysolyn's mask: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1168981 The mask has been resized and adjusted to about 10 X 9 inches (254 mm by 228.6 mm) and sliced into six parts for ease of printing. If you need to make it bigger, measure your face (Forehead to chin and ear to ear) and convert the inches to millimeters in whatever slicing program you work in. The middle portions may need supports. The top portion will need them and will need to be removed with a Dremel (if printed with an 0.8 nozzle or higher). For the visor part, I just used a welding visor and cut it to fit.
https://www.amazon.com/Hobart-770580-Shield-Replacement-Shaded/dp/B002VECKRO/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1483120001&sr=8-1&keywords=welding+visor For the attachment, you can either use elastic or build your own helmet piece out of Worbla, EVA foam, etc.
Happy printing!

comments.text: how did you get the visor to stay in place? Did you use glue? I haven't had the time to print this yet, but I can't wait to!
comments.author: PattersonA

comments.text: Glue and some precise scoring with a soldering Iron around the eye area to get it to hold without popping out or popping someone's eye out. It takes a few tries to get it to fit in, but all I can say is test the fit before you glue the middle and top parts together first.

title: Salsa Jar Wall Mount (for Tostitos salsa jars)

description.text:
Screws securely to (open) Tostitos glass salsa jars so that they may be fastened to a wall and used for storage. If you need to take the jar with you, simply unscrew it from the mount and take it! In the meantime, use it as a cup-holder!
Printed as described, the jar screws and unscrews from the mount with relative ease, but does not separate when pulled (but not turned) by two large adult male humans.

Printer:

Custom

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25 mm layer height

Infill:

25% 3D Honeycomb

Notes: Printed in PLA (MakerGeeks Grey Matter Grey 3.0 mm PLA, 230°C) onto a room-temperature 1/4" lightly-sanded polycarbonate bed, with 0.25 mm layer height, 25% 3D honeycomb infill (Slic3r), and no support material. By default, I use light forced-air cooling, no brim, no raft, a 0.5 mm nozzle, 4 perimeters, and 4 to 5 solid top/bottom layers.
Bend polycarbonate bed, and the print pops right off! Screw to wall, screw on jar, and store your things!
Designed using PTC Creo Pro 3.

author: AMIRSUA

description.text: CHANUKIAH made in about 24 hours

Being now Chanukah epoch, I made this Chanukiah using Autodesk Fusion 360 to model all pieces and then slicing them with Simplify3D. I printed it using white PLA, layer 0.2mm, extruder temperature 185ºC and a 60ºC heated table. Default printing speed 40mm/s. Supports when needed. Print 1 Base, 2 Supports, 1 David (the central Magen David), 1 Candle_cup_1 and 8 Candle_cup_8. It takes time, but it is quite worth. And just to clarify (no pun intended...) the candles are real candles...

comments.text: Here are both files. Have fun ! And a Happy Chanukah !
